title: How to Make Naturally Straight Hair Curly

steps.title: Sleep in braids for loose or tight waves.
steps.content: Sleep in braids for loose or tight waves. When your hair is damp, apply a small amount of styling serum to your fingers and work it through your hair. Divide your hair into however many sections you like and braid each section tightly. You can braid your hair in 2 or more French braids, cornrows, or individual 3-strand braids. Secure the bottoms of each braid with an elastic hairband and sleep on the braids. [1] X Research source In the morning, undo your braids and comb your fingers through your hair. Apply volumizing hairspray to get the curls to stay. For tight waves, divide your hair into many sections and make 6 to 10 small, tight braids when you braid your hair at night. For loose waves, braid your hair into 1 or 2 braids to sleep in.

steps.title: Make pin curls with mini spiral buns.
steps.content: Make pin curls with mini spiral buns. When your hair is damp, take a strand however thick you like, and twist it from top to bottom. When the twist is all the way to your roots, wrap the twist in a circle against your scalp and pin it down with 2 bobby pins crossed over each other. Make these mini buns all over your head, and go to sleep with them in. [2] X Research source Remove the buns in the morning and watch your curls unfold. Spray them with hairspray to make them last for the day. You can make the buns as big or small as you like; use more hair in each twist for bigger buns and looser curls, and less hair in each twist for small buns and tighter curls.

steps.title: Wear a sock-bun overnight for loose curls.
steps.content: Wear a sock-bun overnight for loose curls. When your hair is almost dry after your shower, apply styling serum to it and secure it in a high ponytail with an elastic hairband. Take a sock-bun and put all of your hair through it, then divide your hair in half. Wrap both sections tightly around the sock bun on either side, and secure the ends to your roots with a bobby pin. [3] X Research source Release your hair from the sock-bun in the morning and spray it with hairspray to get your curls to hold. You can purchase sock-buns at beauty supply stores or online, or make your own by cutting the toe out of a sock and rolling the sock up into a thick circle. Keep in mind that a sock bun works best with long hair.

steps.title: Roll your hair in soft curlers overnight for various sized curls.
steps.content: Roll your hair in soft curlers overnight for various sized curls. Purchase soft curling rollers at a beauty supply store. Choose small rollers if you’d like tighter curls, or large roller for loose waves. Wrap your damp hair in the rollers before bed and secure them in place with clips. [4] X Research source Some rollers come with securing clips, which are often easier to use than bobby pins or other hairclips overnight. Others are bendable and you can simply bend them to keep them in place. Unroll your hair from the rollers in the morning and spray your hair with hairspray for curls that last all day.

steps.title: Buy a 1 in (2.5 cm) iron for short or medium length hair.
steps.content: Buy a 1 in (2.5 cm) iron for short or medium length hair. If your hair is only a bit past your shoulders or shorter, you should use a thinner 1 in (2.5 cm) iron for your hair. A thicker one may not give you the amount of curls that you want. [5] X Research source Shop for curling irons online or at beauty supply or department stores. A larger 1.25 in (3.2 cm) thick iron is best to use on hair that’s past shoulder-length. Using a thinner iron may not curl all of your strand each time you roll it up.

steps.title: Apply volumizing mousse or hairspray to your dry, brushed hair.
steps.content: Apply volumizing mousse or hairspray to your dry, brushed hair. Your hair doesn’t need to be freshly washed to begin curling it, but it should free of tangles and dry. Use volumizing mousse or hairspray to coat most of your hair with a thin layer. Be sure to cover the ends of your hair covered with mousse or spray, since those areas are usually the first to lose curl. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Set the iron temperature according to your hair’s thickness.
steps.content: Set the iron temperature according to your hair’s thickness. If you have a curling iron that allows you to change the temperature, you should set your iron at a lower temperature if you have fine hair. Putting too high of heat on fine hair can cause damage to it. For thick hair, set your iron at a higher temperature so the heat gets all of your hair with each time you roll it. [7] X Research source If your hair is fine to medium thickness, or is color-treated, set your iron to 200 °F (93 °C) or below. For thick hair, you can set the temperature to 200–300 °F (93–149 °C).

steps.title: Take a 1 in (2.5 cm) thick section of hair and wrap it around your hot iron.
steps.content: Take a 1 in (2.5 cm) thick section of hair and wrap it around your hot iron. Grab a section of hair between your fingers and wrap the entire strand vertically around your iron once it’s finished heating. [8] X Research source If you have an iron with a clip, you’ll probably want to wrap your hair from the bottom, making sure to clip the very end of your strand in the same direction as you are wrapping the strand up. If you have a wand iron, you can start either at the top or bottom of your hair. For looser waves, start toward the top wherever you want the waves to start and wrap your hair around the wand, leaving a bit of hair out at the ends. For tighter curls with a wand iron, start winding at the bottom and use the upper parts of your hair to cover the ends and keep them close to the iron.

steps.title: Wrap and hold your hair in the iron horizontally for more volume.
steps.content: Wrap and hold your hair in the iron horizontally for more volume. The way that you wrap and hold your hair on your iron effects the type of volume you get with each curl. For tighter curls with more volume, wrap your hair horizontally around the iron and hold it in a horizontal position. [9] X Research source For looser curls with less volume, wrap each strand of hair in your iron vertically, and hold the iron in a vertical position.

steps.title: Keep your hair wrapped in the iron for 8-10 seconds.
steps.content: Keep your hair wrapped in the iron for 8-10 seconds. People are often tempted to keep their hair wrapped in the iron for a longer time, thinking that it will get curlier. Unfortunately, this does not make your hair curlier, but it does damage it. 8-10 seconds is plenty of time to heat each curl around your iron. [10] X Research source You can always go back and redo a curl if you find that it’s not holding well. Try applying more mousse or hairspray to that strand before re-curling it.

steps.title: Pin each curl up gently to let it cool.
steps.content: Pin each curl up gently to let it cool. To help keep each curl locked in, allow it to cool curled up and close to your head. Take a bobby pin (or a single prong clip or duckbill clip) and gently insert it into the curl close to your head to keep the curl up while it cools. [11] X Research source You can leave your curls pinned up as you finish curling the rest of your hair with your iron to save time and keep those finished curls out of your way.

steps.title: Release each cooled curl and spray it with strong or fortifying hair spray.
steps.content: Release each cooled curl and spray it with strong or fortifying hair spray. When you’re finished curling your hair, release each pin from your curls and coat your hair with a layer of hair spray to get them to hold. High-strength or “fortifying” spray will help hold your curls in place longer. [12] X Research source If you have very fine hair, be sure to get just a thin layer of spray on your curls. Your hair won’t need much spray to hold it, and too much spray can actually weigh fine curls down and make them come out. Try an anti-humidity hairspray if you live in a warm, humid climate to keep your curls in when you go outside.

steps.title: Avoid brushing freshly curled hair.
steps.content: Avoid brushing freshly curled hair. You can gently tousle your hair with your fingers or with a hair pick to spread them out and style them, especially if they are staying too tightly in the shape of the iron for your liking. But unless you want to remove your curls or create volume, don’t brush or comb them. Brushing your curls may also create frizz. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Don’t chemically treat your hair for 1 month prior to getting a perm.
steps.content: Don’t chemically treat your hair for 1 month prior to getting a perm. Hair that’s been colored, relaxed, or in any way chemically altered within a month of getting a perm carries extra risk of damage and of the perm not taking to your hair how it’s supposed to. [14] X Research source Some stylists will not apply perms to hair that has been colored or chemically treated at all. Call ahead to find out the perm policies at your salon. Perms can sometimes cause your hair to look lighter in color. Talk to your stylist about whether or not this is a possibility on your hair type. Remember that perms last about 6 months, depending on your hair length and texture. They don’t really fade out, they have to start to grow out.

steps.title: Tell your stylist what type of curls you want.
steps.content: Tell your stylist what type of curls you want. Are you interested in subtle waves, bouncy waves, or classic pin-curls? Let your stylist know how you want your curls to look, and they will tell you your perm options for your hair type and those types of curls. [15] X Research source Browse pictures in style magazines or online to get more ideas for the types of curls you’d like. It’s even better if you can bring a picture in to the salon with you. Your stylist will be able to tell you how your hair type will hold different types of perms.

steps.title: Get a digital or “hot” perm for looser curls on thick hair.
steps.content: Get a digital or “hot” perm for looser curls on thick hair. There are 2 main perm options: digital or “hot” perms and cold or alkaline-compound perms. Hot perms prepare your hair first with a relaxing treatment, then heated rods are applied and the temperature is monitored depending on your hair’s length and thickness. [16] X Research source Digital perms only work on thick hair. They produce looser wave-like curls and not ringlets. The overall process of a digital perm takes about 3-4 hours and is more expensive than cold perms. Digital perms potentially cause less damage to your hair than cold perms, and you need less styling products to help keep the curls in place.

steps.title: Ask for a “cold” perm to get tighter ringlets on any hair texture.
steps.content: Ask for a “cold” perm to get tighter ringlets on any hair texture. If you don’t have thick hair, your only perm option is a cold perm. In this type of perm, your hair is soaked in an alkaline compound and then wound tightly around rollers to create ringlets. Cold perms can get curls closer to your roots and work on any hair type. [17] X Research source While cold perms are less natural-looking at first, they do relax a bit eventually. You have to use curl-enhancing products more frequently on a cold perm, but the overall process is shorter and more affordable.

steps.title: Wait 2-3 days before shampooing freshly permed hair.
steps.content: Wait 2-3 days before shampooing freshly permed hair. After your perm, your hair needs time to adjust to the chemicals and damage done to it during the perm. Your curls also need as much time as possible to set; washing them too soon can cause them to come out a bit. [18] X Research source Use curl-enhancing shampoos, conditioners, and styling products on your permed hair. Use a conditioner containing protein to help your hair recover nutrients lost during the perm process.

steps.title: Don’t rub your hair with a towel when it’s wet.
steps.content: Don’t rub your hair with a towel when it’s wet. To avoid having your hair get frizzy and tangled, gently pat it dry with a microfiber towel after your shower instead of rubbing it. Only dry it enough so that it’s not dripping, and allow it to finish air-drying. [19] X Research source If you got a cold perm, apply curl-enhancing cream or solution to your hair while it’s still damp and allow it to air dry. Avoid heat drying or straightening your hair with a flat-iron when it’s permed. Too much heat can damage permed hair.

steps.title: Avoid dyes and chlorine when you have a perm.
steps.content: Avoid dyes and chlorine when you have a perm. Anything that’s high in chemicals, such as hair color or chlorine, can have a negative effect on your perm, causing it to look dry and damaged. Wait at least 1 month to color-treat permed hair. If you’re a swimmer, wear a swim cap to protect your perm from chlorine until the perm eventually grows and falls out.

steps.title: Get your hair trimmed every 3 months to keep your curls bouncy.
steps.content: Get your hair trimmed every 3 months to keep your curls bouncy. You may be tempted to not cut your hair to try to keep the perm in longer. However, to keep the curls that are there looking bouncy and healthy, you should trim your hair in 3 months. [20] X Research source If your hair grows fast, the top will probably begin to straighten and the bottom curls will look looser over time. Most perms last about 6 months before they begin to fall out completely.

steps.title: Wash your hair thoroughly with shampoo and conditioner and let air dry for 5 minutes.
steps.content: Wash your hair thoroughly with shampoo and conditioner and let air dry for 5 minutes. If you want 10x better results, use a shampoo and conditioner made for curly hair. This can help the curls be more defined.

steps.title: Brush hair thoroughly.
steps.content: Brush hair thoroughly. After, scrunch hair with your hands or a dry towel on wet hair without using any products. This will form a good starting position for the curls and make it easier to work with when styling. Do not brush after scrunching the hair, as this will make the curls fall and have no shape

steps.title: Gather products and tools you will be using on your hair.
steps.content: Gather products and tools you will be using on your hair. These products are all from "Not Your Mother's Curl Talk."

steps.title: Section out your hair into two sections.
steps.content: Section out your hair into two sections. Put one half up in a clip and leave one half down. This will allow you to coat every part of your hair with products.

steps.title: Apply the defining cream to your hands and run this throughout the hair you have down.
steps.content: Apply the defining cream to your hands and run this throughout the hair you have down. If you think there are not enough products, you can add more but don't overdo it.

steps.title: Brush through your hair again with the product in, but again do not overdo the brushing.
steps.content: Brush through your hair again with the product in, but again do not overdo the brushing. The more you brush the less product will be in your hair and the less effective the curls will be.

steps.title: Scrunch in the sculpting gel to the hair with your hands.
steps.content: Scrunch in the sculpting gel to the hair with your hands. Apply to the hair you already have down in which you just applied the defining cream to. Do not brush through your hair this time. You will not brush hair from this point forward because the curls will not form.

steps.title: Scrunch in the activating mouse on the hair you still have down.
steps.content: Scrunch in the activating mouse on the hair you still have down. By doing this it will add texture, and definition to your hair which can give it a fuller appearance.

steps.title: Use your finger to coil some of the hair strands, or use the end of your brush in place of your finger.
steps.content: Use your finger to coil some of the hair strands, or use the end of your brush in place of your finger. Hold for a minimum of 30 seconds for each strand. The longer you hold this the better, but it is up to you. To do this, start from the bottom of the hair strand and use your finger to wrap upward. An alternative is to use the end of a brush to wrap the hair around. For a better curl, hold for at least 30 seconds or longer.

steps.title: Take the half of your hair you have up, down and repeat steps 5-9 to the top part of your hair.
steps.content: Take the half of your hair you have up, down and repeat steps 5-9 to the top part of your hair. Make sure you evenly spread the products through the hair and to the roots

steps.title: Use a dry towel or a cotton t-shirt to scrunch up the excess water.
steps.content: Use a dry towel or a cotton t-shirt to scrunch up the excess water. When scrunching hold for at least 5 seconds, this will form the curls better and remove more water from the hair. This will also better form the existing curls.

steps.title: Let the hair air dry or you can use a hair diffuser to help hair dry faster.
steps.content: Let the hair air dry or you can use a hair diffuser to help hair dry faster. When using a hair diffuser, start by diffusing at the roots on medium heat and work your way down to the ends of your hair carefully. If you want you can tilt your hair upside down to get underneath and add some volume. Gently touch the hair with the diffuser and do not be rough.

steps.title: Finished Look.
steps.content: Finished Look.
